stem: The nurse is using an AI-assisted documentation tool ('Scribe' technology). For each action, select whether it is Clinically Ethical or an Ethical Violation under 2026 digital standards.

rows.text: Obtaining explicit patient consent before using an AI-assisted voice recorder during an assessment.
Copying and pasting AI-generated text directly into the EHR without verifying or editing the clinical facts.
Using a non-encrypted consumer-grade AI tool to 'summarize' a patient's complex pathology report.
Reporting a 'hallucination' (fabricated medical data) found in an AI-generated draft to the hospital informatics team.

rationale.correct: AI tools in nursing require human oversight ('Human-in-the-loop'). (r1) Consent is mandatory for any digital recording. (r2) 'Automation Bias'—trusting AI without verification—is a major source of 2026 medical errors. The nurse is always responsible for the final note. (r3) Personal AI tools lack the Data Processing Agreements (DPA) required by HIPAA. (r4) Transparency and reporting of digital errors improve systemic safety.
rationale.incorrect: AI is a 'tool' to support the nurse, not a 'provider' to replace the nurse's clinical judgment.
clinicalPearls: AI model 'hallucinations' can lead to patients being assigned incorrect diagnoses or medications. Always verify AI-generated output against your own direct assessment.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember that saving time does not justify cutting corners on data privacy or clinical accuracy. If the AI tool isn't hospital-vetted, it's a violation.

mnemonic.title: A-I-C-A-R-E
mnemonic.expansion: Always Verify, Informed Consent, Controlled Access (Institutional), Report Hallucinations, Ethical Oversight.

reviewUnits.heading: Artificial Intelligence in Nursing Documentation
reviewUnits.body: Nurses must navigate the 'Digital Frontier' with caution. AI can summarize notes, but the nurse remains the legal author and is responsible for every word in the medical record.
reviewUnits.source: ANA: Artificial Intelligence in Nursing Practice
